text: Still a bit confused on using MLJ. Does it not work such that for example in LogisticClassifier I can't just feed in a regular Julia matrix? I always get these scitype warnings and I'm not sure why. Being used to scikit learn in Python usually just fit(X,y) works. What is the issue with my Xtrain_sc variable here its just a regular matrix

elements.text: Still a bit confused on using MLJ. Does it not work such that for example in LogisticClassifier I can't just feed in a regular Julia matrix? I always get these scitype warnings and I'm not sure why. Being used to scikit learn in Python usually just fit(X,y) works. What is the issue with my Xtrain_sc variable here its just a regular matrix

text:
Not an MLJ expert by any means, but the short answer is that there are a few more steps to do before just plugging in the data.

Certain algorithms are only made to work on certain data types (i.e. categorical or continuous) and so the scitype stuff is essentially you mapping your data to its "data type". There are some automations and pipelining and validations that it enables. 

Once you get the hang of it, it's pretty quick, and essentially negligible amount of time compared to the rest of the stuff you do with a dataset.

Some of the warnings you could ignore if you wanted, but it may not be best practice or statistically meaningful (e.g. like doing regression on categorical data)

text: I was following this <https://alan-turing-institute.github.io/DataScienceTutorials.jl/isl/lab-4/>. And for my binary Y, I did make it an ordered factor. But even this guide does not seem to do any coerce() to the X

elements.text: . And for my binary Y, I did make it an ordered factor. But even this guide does not seem to do any coerce() to the X

text: I just used MLJ.table() on my X and it actually crashed it, maybe cause I didn't suppress the printing

elements.text: I just used MLJ.table() on my X and it actually crashed it, maybe cause I didn't suppress the printing

text:
The solution is to wrap the matrix `Xsc` in a Table (e.g `DataFrame`, `MatrixTable`, etc.).
To use wrap a matrix `Xsc`in a matrix table do `MLJ.table(Xs);`. Yes for tables with large no. of columns you may want to add `;` to suppress the output.
I think the show method for the `MatrixTable` type has to be improved to avoid this issue in the future.
